topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Teresa Torres, her book Continuous Discovery Habits, and her impact on the product community. Teresa shares where to find her work and courses.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Persona and Dovetail, focused on identity verification/onboarding and user research tooling.

topics.title: Opportunity Solution Tree overview and purpose
topics.summary: Teresa explains the Opportunity Solution Tree (OST): outcome at the root, branching into opportunities, solutions, and assumption tests. She frames it as scaffolding for teams shifting from output/feature delivery to outcome-driven decision-making.

topics.title: Netflix example: mapping opportunities via experience map
topics.summary: Using streaming entertainment, Teresa shows how to structure the opportunity space around the end-to-end customer journey (trigger, choosing, evaluating, viewing, post-viewing). She emphasizes opportunities are needs/pain points, not solutions, and are often shared across competitors.

topics.title: Sizing and decomposing opportunities in the tree
topics.summary: They discuss keeping the top-level opportunity branches cognitively manageable (roughly 3–7). Teresa explains how moving down the tree decomposes big evergreen problems into smaller, solvable opportunities while still contributing to the larger outcome.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Stytch, highlighting authentication and onboarding APIs/SDKs and conversion improvements.

topics.title: How to populate the tree: interviews and opportunity framing
topics.summary: Teresa explains opportunities come from customer stories, not abstract Q&A. She outlines why teams struggle: poor interviewing, confusing solutions with opportunities, and framing opportunities too vaguely instead of specific, actionable pain points.

topics.title: Using OST in feature-factory organizations
topics.summary: Teresa advises ICs not to force org change but to change how they work: talk to customers even without permission, use personal networks, and build context around business outcomes. Continuous discovery improves day-to-day decisions even with a prescribed roadmap.

topics.title: Defining continuous discovery and why it matters
topics.summary: Teresa defines discovery as deciding what to build and argues it should be customer-centric and continuous because digital products are never “done.” She contrasts project-based mindsets with continuous improvement and feedback loops.

topics.title: When leaders say there’s no time for discovery
topics.summary: Teresa reframes the objection as resistance to project-based research, not continuous discovery. She emphasizes everything in the backlog is a bet; teams should keep delivering while adding lightweight discovery in parallel to improve bet quality over time.

topics.title: Automating weekly customer interviews and recruiting
topics.summary: Teresa shares systems to make interviews a recurring habit: in-product opt-ins (like NPS-style intercepts) feeding scheduling tools, and leveraging sales/support/account teams to recruit buyers/decision-makers. Goal: wake up with interviews already on the calendar.

topics.title: Staying open-minded: risk, measurement, and multiple solutions
topics.summary: Teresa explains not every problem needs heavy discovery; focus on core differentiators and higher-risk bets. Instrumentation and measuring impact help calibrate risk, and generating multiple solution options prevents overcommitting to the “obvious” idea.

topics.title: Decision-making: product trio collaboration vs PM as decider
topics.summary: Teresa critiques siloed, political role-based decision-making and advocates for empowered product trios (PM, design, engineering) making decisions together. Shared understanding reduces disagreement; when conflict remains, it signals the team needs better options.

topics.title: Interviewing mistakes and how to elicit real stories
topics.summary: Teresa highlights common interviewing errors: overly scripted question lists and shallow follow-ups. She demonstrates story-based interviewing (“tell me about the last time…”, “what happened next?”), emphasizing behavior over hypotheticals and the importance of deep listening.

topics.title: Scaling discovery and defending small-sample insights
topics.summary: Teresa argues the core discovery unit (empowered trio + outcome + weekly interviews + assumption testing) should remain consistent as companies scale, with added cross-team coordination. She addresses skepticism about small samples: one customer is better than zero, and product work relies on iterative feedback loops and experiments over time.
